questions.question: In a triangle, two interior angles measure <math><mn>54</mn><mo>°</mo></math> and <math><mn>71</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of the third interior angle?
questions.explanation: The sum of the interior angles of a triangle is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The third angle is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>54</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>71</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>55</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When you see a triangle, check if angle sum <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math> applies immediately.

questions.question: Two adjacent angles form a straight line. One angle measures <math><mn>112</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of the other angle?
questions.explanation: Angles that form a straight line are supplementary and sum to <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The other angle is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>112</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>68</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If the figure is a straight line, write <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math> right away.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='300' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='100' y1='50' x2='300' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='190' y='180' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><text x='130' y='155' font-size='14'>60°</text><text x='250' y='155' font-size='14'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two straight lines intersecting at point O to form an X shape. The angle on the left is labeled 60 degrees. The angle on the right, vertically opposite to it, is labeled x degrees.
questions.question: In the figure, two lines intersect at point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math>. One of the angles measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>60</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Vertical angles are congruent (equal). Since <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> is vertical to the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>60</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> angle (opposite across the intersection), <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='100' y1='250' x2='300' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='100' y1='50' x2='300' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='190' y='180' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><text x='130' y='155' font-size='14'>60°</text><text x='250' y='155' font-size='14' fill='red'>x=60°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The intersecting lines with the vertical angle x highlighted in red and labeled as 60 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for the 'X' shape. Angles opposite each other at the intersection (vertical angles) are always equal.

questions.question: Triangle ABC is isosceles with <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. If angle A measures <math><mn>38</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure of angle B in degrees? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: If <math><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, then angles B and C are equal. Let each be <math><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo></math>. Then <math><mn>38</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, so <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>142</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>71</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In an isosceles triangle, equal sides are opposite equal angles; set the two base angles equal immediately.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='350' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='140' y1='250' x2='260' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M230 100 A 30 30 0 0 0 248 70' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='255' y='85' font-size='16' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>m°</text><path d='M170 200 A 30 30 0 0 0 188 170' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='195' y='185' font-size='16'>132°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two parallel horizontal lines intersected by a slanted transversal. Angle m is at the top intersection in the upper-right position. The angle labeled 132 degrees is at the bottom intersection, also in the upper-right position.
questions.question: In the figure, the two horizontal lines are parallel. The angle labeled <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>m</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> and the angle labeled <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>132</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> are corresponding angles. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, corresponding angles (angles in the same relative position at each intersection) are congruent. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>132</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='50' y1='100' x2='350' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='50' y1='200' x2='350' y2='200' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='140' y1='250' x2='260' y2='50' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M230 100 A 30 30 0 0 0 248 70' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='255' y='85' font-size='16' fill='red'>m=132°</text><path d='M170 200 A 30 30 0 0 0 188 170' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='195' y='185' font-size='16' fill='red'>132°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The figure with both corresponding angles highlighted in red and labeled 132 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify corresponding angles by their position: they are on the same side of the transversal and in the same spot (e.g., top-right) at every intersection.

questions.question: In triangle PQR, the measure of the exterior angle at vertex Q is <math><mn>118</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. If angle P measures <math><mn>47</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure of angle R?
questions.explanation: An exterior angle equals the sum of the two remote interior angles. So <math><mn>118</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>47</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>r</mi></math>, where <math><mi>r</mi></math> is the measure of angle R in degrees. Then <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>71</mn></math>, so angle R measures <math><mn>71</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Exterior angle theorem is often faster than using <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math> twice.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 200,150 350,250' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><line x1='120' y1='195' x2='130' y2='205' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='270' y1='205' x2='280' y2='195' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='35' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='355' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='195' y='140' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='195' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><path d='M80 250 A 40 40 0 0 1 75 230' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='85' y='245' font-size='14'>34°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Isosceles triangle ABC with base AC. A dashed line connects vertex B to the midpoint D on the base. Angle A is labeled 34 degrees. Tick marks on sides AB and BC indicate they are equal in length.
questions.question: In the figure, triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is isosceles with <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. Segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is drawn from <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math> to the midpoint <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi></math> of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. If angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>34</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, what is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, the base angles are equal, so <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>34</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. The sum of angles in a triangle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, so the total vertex angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mn>34</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mn>34</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>112</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. In an isosceles triangle, the median to the base is also the angle bisector. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>112</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>56</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='50,250 200,150 350,250' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='150' x2='200' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><text x='35' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='355' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='195' y='140' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='195' y='265' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><path d='M80 250 A 40 40 0 0 1 75 230' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='85' y='245' font-size='14'>34°</text><path d='M320 250 A 40 40 0 0 0 325 230' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='285' y='245' font-size='14' fill='red'>34°</text><path d='M200 180 A 40 40 0 0 0 215 175' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='205' y='195' font-size='14' fill='red'>56°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The triangle with angle C identified as 34 degrees and the bisected vertex angle DBC identified as 56 degrees.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In an isosceles triangle, the line connecting the vertex to the midpoint of the base acts as a median, altitude, and angle bisector simultaneously.

questions.question: Two lines intersect. One angle at the intersection measures <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, and its adjacent angle measures <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: Adjacent angles at an intersection that form a straight line are supplementary: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. So <math><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>, giving <math><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Translate words like “adjacent on a straight line” into one equation: sum equals <math><mn>180</mn></math>.

questions.question: Line <math><mi>l</mi></math> has slope <math><mn>2</mn></math>. Line <math><mi>m</mi></math> is perpendicular to line <math><mi>l</mi></math>. What is the slope of line <math><mi>m</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For non-vertical perpendicular lines, the slopes are negative reciprocals. The negative reciprocal of <math><mn>2</mn></math> is <math><mn>-</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Perpendicular slopes multiply to <math><mn>-</mn><mn>1</mn></math> (when both slopes are defined).

questions.question: In triangle XYZ, angle X measures <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, angle Y measures <math><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, and angle Z measures <math><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Use the triangle angle sum: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Then <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>, so <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></math> and <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Write one angle-sum equation first; solve before looking at choices.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white' /><line x1='20' y1='70' x2='400' y2='70' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='20' y1='210' x2='400' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='75' y1='255' x2='240' y2='29' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='210' y1='70' x2='312' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='108' y1='210' x2='312' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='108' cy='210' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='115' y='230' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><circle cx='312' cy='210' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='320' y='230' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><circle cx='210' cy='70' r='3' fill='black' /><text x='230' y='60' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><path d='M 180 70 A 30 30 0 0 1 228 45' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='185' y='55' font-size='14'>126°</text><path d='M 282 210 A 30 30 0 0 1 298 190' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='275' y='205' font-size='14'>54°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Two parallel horizontal lines intersected by a transversal. Triangle ABC is formed between the parallel lines. Point C is on the top line; points A and B are on the bottom line. The transversal passes through A and C. An obtuse angle of 126 degrees is marked outside the parallel lines at the top intersection (formed by the transversal and the top line). Angle B inside the triangle is marked as 54 degrees.
questions.question: In the figure, the two horizontal lines are parallel. Segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> lies on the transversal. The angle formed by the transversal and the upper line is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>126</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> (as shown). Angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>54</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. What is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
1. **Find Angle CAB:** The angle marked 126∘ and the interior angle at the top intersection form a linear pair (or we can use alternate interior angles directly if identifying the correct geometry). The acute angle adjacent to 126∘ on the straight line is 180∘-126∘=54∘. Since the horizontal lines are parallel, the alternate interior angle at A (inside the triangle) is equal to this acute angle. Thus, ∠CAB=54∘.
2. **Find Angle ACB:** In triangle ABC, the sum of angles is 180∘. We know ∠CAB=54∘ and ∠ABC=54∘.
Therefore, ∠ACB=180∘-(54∘+54∘)=180∘-108∘=72∘.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white' /><line x1='20' y1='70' x2='400' y2='70' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='20' y1='210' x2='400' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='75' y1='255' x2='240' y2='29' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='210' y1='70' x2='312' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='108' y1='210' x2='312' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='115' y='230' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='320' y='230' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='225' y='60' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='185' y='55' font-size='14'>126°</text><path d='M 138 210 A 30 30 0 0 0 125 186' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='140' y='200' font-size='12' fill='red'>54°</text><path d='M 198 90 A 30 30 0 0 0 220 90' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='200' y='115' font-size='12' fill='red'>72°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The diagram highlights the calculated angles. 1) The alternate interior angle at A is shown in red as 54 degrees. 2) The missing angle at C is shown in red as 72 degrees, derived from the triangle sum.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a transversal cuts parallel lines, calculate all the simple angles (acute and obtuse) at the intersections first. They will either be equal or supplementary.

questions.question: In triangle DEF, angle D measures <math><mn>28</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The bisector of angle E divides angle E into two angles that each measure <math><mn>41</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of angle F?
questions.explanation: Angle E is split into two equal angles of <math><mn>41</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, so angle E is <math><mn>82</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Then angle F is <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>28</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>82</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>70</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Therefore the correct value is <math><mn>70</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If an angle is bisected, double the given half-angle before using triangle sum.

questions.question: In triangle ABC, angle A measures <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, angle B measures <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, and angle C measures <math><mn>70</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: Use the triangle angle sum: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>70</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Then <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>, so <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Combine like terms immediately; it prevents arithmetic slips on multi-angle equations.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white' /><polygon points='80,230 340,230 210,50' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='210' y1='50' x2='210' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='60' y='235' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='350' y='235' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='205' y='40' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='215' y='245' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><path d='M100 230 A 20 20 0 0 1 106 215' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='110' y='225' font-size='14'>50°</text><path d='M200 80 A 40 40 0 0 1 210 82' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='185' y='100' font-size='14'>x°</text><path d='M210 82 A 40 40 0 0 1 220 80' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='225' y='100' font-size='14'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: An isosceles triangle ABC with AB = BC. The base AC is horizontal. A line segment BD is drawn from the top vertex B to the base AC, bisecting the angle B. Angle A is labeled 50 degrees. The two angles at B formed by the bisector (angle ABD and angle DBC) are both labeled x degrees.
questions.question: In the figure, triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is isosceles with <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. Point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi></math> lies on segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, and segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is drawn. Angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, and angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. If angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> also measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>x</mi><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is isosceles, which means the base angles are equal: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. The sum of angles in a triangle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, so the vertex angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>80</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. The segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> divides <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> into two angles of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></math>, which gives <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white' /><polygon points='80,230 340,230 210,50' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='210' y1='50' x2='210' y2='230' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='60' y='235' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='350' y='235' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='205' y='40' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><path d='M320 230 A 20 20 0 0 0 314 215' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='300' y='225' font-size='14' fill='red'>50°</text><text x='215' y='120' font-size='14' fill='red'>Total 80°</text><path d='M200 80 A 40 40 0 0 1 220 80' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The diagram illustrates the isosceles triangle properties. Angle C is highlighted in red as 50 degrees (equal to Angle A). The vertex angle B is highlighted in red as the remaining 80 degrees from the 180-degree sum.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a segment splits an angle into equal parts, write a quick 'two pieces sum to the whole' equation.

questions.question: In triangle JKL, angle K is a right angle. Angle J measures <math><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>°</mo></math>, and angle L measures <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>t</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Angle K is <math><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Using angle sum: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>90</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>. Then <math><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>95</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>, so <math><mn>5</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>85</mn></math> and <math><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a right angle is given, substitute <math><mn>90</mn></math> immediately to reduce steps.

questions.question: Lines <math><mi>p</mi></math> and <math><mi>q</mi></math> are parallel and cut by a transversal. One of the interior angles between the lines measures <math><mn>97</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of the alternate interior angle?
questions.explanation: Alternate interior angles are congruent when lines are parallel. Therefore the alternate interior angle also measures <math><mn>97</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For parallel lines, memorize: corresponding and alternate interior angles are equal; same-side interior angles sum to <math><mn>180</mn></math>.

questions.question: Two lines intersect to form four angles. One angle measures <math><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>, and the vertical angle measures <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>22</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: Vertical angles are congruent, so set them equal: <math><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>22</mn></math>. Then <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For intersecting lines, start by deciding whether you need a vertical-angle equation (equal) or a linear-pair equation (sum to <math><mn>180</mn></math>).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white' /><polygon points='60,240 300,240 200,70' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='70' x2='240' y2='240' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='45' y='250' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='310' y='250' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='195' y='60' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='235' y='260' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><path d='M190 105 A 40 40 0 0 1 208 105' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='185' y='125' font-size='12'>35°</text><path d='M212 105 A 40 40 0 0 1 220 100' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='225' y='115' font-size='12'>25°</text><path d='M80 240 A 20 20 0 0 0 85 225' fill='none' stroke='black' /><text x='85' y='235' font-size='12'>50°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Triangle ABC with point D lying on the base segment AC. A line connects vertex B to point D. The angle at vertex A is 50 degrees. The angle at vertex B is split into two parts: angle ABD is 35 degrees and angle DBC is 25 degrees.
questions.question: In triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>, point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi></math> lies on segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. Segment <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is drawn so that angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>35</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> and angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>25</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>. If angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>50</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math>, what is the measure of angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi></math>?
questions.explanation:
1. **Find Angle ABC:** The total angle at B is the sum of the split angles: ∠ABC=35∘+25∘=60∘.
2. **Find Angle C:** The sum of angles in triangle ABC is 180∘. We have ∠A=50∘ and ∠B=60∘. Thus, ∠C=180∘-(50∘+60∘)=70∘.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='280' viewBox='0 0 420 280' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='280' fill='white' /><polygon points='60,240 300,240 200,70' stroke='black' fill='none' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='70' x2='240' y2='240' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='45' y='250' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='310' y='250' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>C</text><text x='195' y='60' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='235' y='260' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>D</text><path d='M190 105 A 40 40 0 0 1 220 100' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='180' y='100' font-size='12' fill='red'>60°</text><path d='M280 240 A 30 30 0 0 1 270 215' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='280' y='210' font-size='12' fill='red'>70°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The diagram highlights the calculated total angle B (60 degrees) and the resulting angle C (70 degrees) in red.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If an angle is split into two labeled angles, add them first to find the total vertex angle before using the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mn>180</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></math> triangle sum rule.

questions.question: In triangle MNO, angle M measures <math><mn>46</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. A line through N is drawn parallel to segment MO, forming an angle of <math><mi>k</mi><mo>°</mo></math> with segment NM on the outside of the triangle. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The line through N is parallel to MO, so the angle it makes with NM corresponds to angle M. The corresponding interior angle is <math><mn>46</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, but the angle asked is an exterior angle on the outside, which is supplementary: <math><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>46</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>134</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Parallel lines create corresponding angles; then decide whether the problem asks for the interior angle or its supplement.

questions.question: In triangle RST, angles R and S are congruent. Angle T measures <math><mn>34</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of angle R in degrees? (Enter an integer.)
questions.explanation: If angles R and S are congruent, let each be <math><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo></math>. Then <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>34</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn></math>, so <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>146</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>73</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When you see two congruent angles, replace both with a single variable before using the <math><mn>180</mn></math> sum.
